title: 110_hr2040
content:
The "Civil Rights Act of 1964 Commemorative Coin Act" commemorates key events in the civil rights movement, including Rosa Parks' defiance on a segregated bus, college students' lunch counter sit-ins, and the Freedom Rides testing segregation in interstate transportation. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. led civil rights supporters in the March on Washington in 1963, delivering his famous "I Have A Dream" speech to raise awareness for civil rights legislation. Mrs. Coretta Scott King was a prominent figure in the civil rights movement, organizing Freedom Concerts and participating in marches alongside her husband. The Civil Rights Act of 1964, influenced by Rosa Parks and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., expanded civil rights protections, outlawing racial discrimination and segregation in public places, federally funded programs, and employment. It also encouraged desegregation in public schools and served as a model for subsequent anti-discrimination laws. Equality in education was a cornerstone of the civil rights movement, with Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. emphasizing the importance of education for shaping the future. The United Negro College Fund has supported over 300,000 young African Americans in earning college degrees, including leaders in various fields like education, science, medicine, and law. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 marked a significant milestone in the fight against discrimination. Congress has a duty to continue this struggle for equal rights. The act specifies the minting of $1 coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. These coins are legal tender according to the law. The coins minted under this Act are considered numismatic items and shall have designs emblematic of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Each coin will bear a value designation, the year "2014", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.
Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2014, with sales initiated before that date. Minting authority terminates on December 31, 2014.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.
Coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.
    (a) Surcharge Required.--Sales must include a $10 surcharge per coin.
    (b) Distribution.--Surcharges received by the Secretary will be promptly paid to the United Negro College Fund (UNCF) to support their activities. The United Negro College Fund (UNCF) receives funds for scholarships, internships, and technology services for historically black colleges. The Fund is subject to audit requirements. No surcharge can be included if it exceeds the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to carry out the United States Code as in effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.
